title: My Child Struggles with Borrowing in Subtraction – A Clear Guide
description: Breaking down why regrouping (borrowing) is confusing and concrete strategies to help it click.

content.intro: Borrowing (regrouping) trips up countless kids. They understand basic subtraction, but as soon as the top digit is smaller than the bottom, everything falls apart. Here's how to help.

items: It's abstract – "borrowing from the tens place" is conceptually weird
Multiple steps to track (cross out, add, remember to reduce)
Easy to forget to reduce the borrowed-from digit

sections.text: Before teaching the algorithm, make sure your child understands:

items: Numbers can be decomposed: 52 = 4 tens + 12 ones

sections.text: Base-10 blocks make borrowing concrete. To solve 52-38:

items: "Can we take 8 units? We only have 2"
Now we have 4 tens and 12 ones
Take away 3 tens and 8 ones = 1 ten and 4 ones = 14

sections.text: For 52-38: Start at 38, count up to 52. 38→40 is 2, 40→50 is 10, 50→52 is 2. Total: 14.
The traditional algorithm is efficient but conceptually difficult. Make sure your child understands WHY borrowing works before drilling the procedure.

items: Start with single-digit subtraction facts (solid foundation)

faq.question: Why does my child borrow when they don't need to?
faq.answer: They're probably applying a rule without understanding. Go back to the question: "Is the top number big enough to subtract the bottom number?" If yes, no borrowing needed.

faq.question: Borrowing across zeros is a nightmare. Any tips?
faq.answer: Practice "chaining" – when you borrow from a zero, you need to borrow from the next place first. Use expanded form or manipulatives to show 400 = 3 hundreds + 10 tens = 3 hundreds + 9 tens + 10 ones.

faq.question: Should I teach an alternative method?
faq.answer: If the standard algorithm isn't clicking, yes. The number line method and counting up are excellent alternatives that some kids find more intuitive.

cta.text: SoroKid teaches subtraction with soroban – a visual, hands-on approach that makes regrouping intuitive.
